Posts.Content: Dear Rebecca. I have had the same procedure as you, save I have to have chemo next. I know it is hard but if you look back on this site there has been discussions regarding voluntary mx. There was a quote, can't remember who said that they had been told by a surgeon if you had one bad leg, you would not take the other just in case. I think that this is a good point. None of us know why're got this and how long we have had it but we cannot, in my view,go having invasive surgery unnecessarily. I understand there might well be a higher chance of us getting it in the other breast but I personally would not choose this course. I am coping ok with losing one breast not sure if I would cope with the loss of both and especially if there was no medical reason. We all have personal choices to make and this is one for you. I would not however, choose this course. I am not sure that this is helpful but it is a view. Good luck with any decision you make. Benja x
Posts.Title: Thinking of voluntary MX

Posts.Content: Hi really pleased to read these postings as I am having my PICC line removed next week and I was dreading it as it was awful when it was put in. Now I am relaxed. Thank you. Benja x
Posts.Title: PICC Line

Posts.Content: Hi, you have had a great response from Dreamthief with the info. Just to let you know I suffered with this on Doxatacel  back in 2013 and also red hand and foot syndrome , my dosage was reduced on the last chemo. I still have some numbness in my fingers and toes but much better now. Just be careful when washing up, I broke glasses and plates galore and invested in a padding for the sink as I couldn't feel anything! Good excuse to get out of the washing up and buy new crockery!  It does get better. Good luck with your journey. Benja xx
Posts.Title: numbness in fingers and toes

Posts.Content: Hi Jenny I was petrified just before my MX on November 2nd, I took a week holiday with the hubby and kids and came back to the controversy of whether there was 'over treatment ' of breast cancer. I was ready to do a runner! I have to say that once I was there and following the MX and a node clearance as it had spread, I have no regrets. I have not missed my breast like I thought I would, in my mind I have had the disease cut out and those who have seen it have all remarked that it is better than they expected. Of course it is an emotional time, we have all had a good cry and it takes time to come to terms with it. We all deal in our own way . Focus on the positives and practicalities as you seem to. You will get through it and on this site there are lots of ladies who will help you along the way.we all have bad days,it's normal. Pogue-Mahone I am 12 days it would seem ahead of you. I had my first FEC on 18th December and second is next week. It is doable, just make sure you have the sickness tablet at least an hour before treatment ( they had not given me the tablet) and that you take all the anti sickness course they give to you. I had a rough night and was physically sick but then the nausea continued for a few days after and some mouth ulcers. That was it, so with some bonjella, a mouth wash from the hospital and ice cream it has been fine. Good luck to you both Benja xx
Posts.Title: Weeks following mx

Posts.Content: Hi I had a joint critical illness with my hubbie which I claimed on, paid out within three months of diagnosis and was relatively straightforward. Just found out that it cancelled the policy for hubbie so just hastily arranged cover for him knowing that it can happen to anyone. An important lesson that I now expound to everyone. Also I was told I cannot have critical illness for at least five years and that there will be companies that now won't cover me at all, I expected cancer but not everything. I also had a policy through work I paid for my earnings which could be claimed after thirteen weeks , this is proving a little less straightforward to claim on and despite starting a claim in January am still battling to push it forward which is frustrating. It does take the pressure off to have some monies behind you as I have heard several horror stories of women having to work through this horrible journey and others who couldn't losing their houses in the process. I am glad that more luck than judgement I had the policies in place as they have given me piece of mind and I can concentrate on kicking this disease and taking back my life. Good luck with your journey but do claim, it's worth the piece of mind. Love Benja xxx
Posts.Title: Insurance claims

Posts.Content: Hi Sraine. I too have been suffering for a few months with hot flushes from Tamoxifen. It has been so bad I was becoming nocturnal ! Have been back to the doctors and to the oncologist about managing the hot flushes. I have been placed on Dixarit ( Used for high blood pressure when I have low blood pressure) I take two 25mg three times a day. It has helped a bit. I also take evening primrose oil. I am due to go back to try another drug in a few weeks time as I am still awake a couple of times a night with the hot flushes. I will post when my medication is altered again. Can't help with the red clover but please let me know if it works. Good luck with the journey. Benja x
Posts.Title: Red clover isoflavones for menopausal symptoms

Posts.Content: Hi I am having really bad hot flushes and sweats at the moment. I too am on Tamoxifen. I was unsure what to do as I thought it might be the early menopause as well. Do let me know if the tablets work as I will then make enquiries, I am not getting much sleep, was up at 3.15am ! Benja x
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen, hot flushes and night sweats and oxybutynin

Posts.Content: Hi Millsam , I have just read your posting with interest. I went the the GP about the hot flushes and the fact I have not slept once through the night since being on Tamoxifen and am resembling a zombie! The GP has out me on Dixarit tablets, 25 micrograms twice a day. I have been taking them for five days and no improvement. I am speaking to GP on Monday and she has said she will increase the dose if there is no improvement . Dixarit is for high blood pressure normally ( although I understand it is used for hot flushes) but I have low blood pressure anyway ! Has anyone else any experience of Dixarit please. Benja xx
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen, hot flushes and night sweats and oxybutynin

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha, I have read your postings and identify with you and I have yet to have my mx. I have just been on holiday and there are pics with me and a cleavage ( the last for quite a while as I am not able to have a reconstruction immediately either). I am struggling with this concept and even have been commenting to my husband 'last Saturday with two breasts, last Sunday etc' Poor man doesn't know what to say. Come Friday I will be the same as you and am not sure how I will cope ( although I am sure I will somehow). I have even thought of backing out of surgery, stupid perhaps but following the report in the news I had convinced myself I had options to avoid the surgery. I really feel for you and can only hope that you will become more positive although this will not be easy. Please let us know how your coping and we can all try and help each other through this life changing time. My thoughts are with you. Virtual hugs. Benja x
Posts.Title: Does it stay llike this?

Posts.Content: Hi. I have finished three FEC and have one Dosetaxal under my belt. I am due my second on Wednesday . I did not have any real side effects until two days after although all food tasted of nothing. I had the booster injection thursday afternoon and by Friday evening the effects started. I had taken painkillers (tramadol) in readiness but I have to say even taking the maximum did not touch the pain in my bones. It varies from a dull ache to shooting pains and sleep was not easy for a week. I also had an allergic reaction to the booster and swelled up in my face,lips and tongue. I thought this was normal but it is not! I ended up on antihistamine as well as nystan for oral thrush. The consultant did say that tramadol does not touch the pain in bones so gave me amitriptyline which did help. I did also develop red hand and foot syndrome on the Wednesday which was painful and my skin is now peeling off. I am on pyridoxine three times a day now until the end of my chemo. I also was recommended udder cream ( yes the stuff used for cows and I have had many jokes about it as you can imagine! ) luckily living in Somerset I was able to get it easily enough but it does seem to be helping. it sounds horrendous and for me has been worse than FEC but as has been said it is doable. Don't be put off by my posting, this is my experience only and doesn't happen to everyone. I posted so that you know the worst and what to look for, don't suffer the hospital can prescribe for all side effects and in my case reactions. Good luck to you all and hope you all have the least side effects. I will post at the weekend and let you know if it was different this time. Love Benja xx
Posts.Title: Finished fec and start tax on Wednesday but feeling really nervous...

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy-loo Had a rough day yesterday but not through the chemo! Saw the oncologist and I was told that I am border line for rads, which from diagnosis I have always been told was on the cards so was a shock. When I started questioning why turns out that it is a postcode lottery, there are no stats to look at for percentages for for and against for one to three nodes involved. I had my sentinel node only. They want me to be a fatalist and for a computer to decide whether I go on with rads or not. If I went to other NHS districts then they will give rads. Basically I received no guidance and was told they recommend no rads but there is no hard and fast rule why, it's just their way! It has been left as it is a gray area and I ghetto decide with no guidance. I was completely floored by the responses and felt very unsupported. There is no information to read as there are no stats available and I am to gamble. I have two fairly young children and my decisions effect them and my family. If it comes back will I not wonder what if? I was told I was discussed at the MDT meeting but when I went to look at my records was declined until I wrote in. Despite mine and many other files being left lying around o the floor and sides for all to see. The chemo was delayed did not get out until 6.45 pm as they were so far behind from a three o'clock app. taste buds are just going now so by tomorrow evening, if the same will be in bad with the pain. Glad to hear yours was not too bad also. Good you have Regress I am in limbo now and would welcome any thoughts. The family feel I should insist on rads which I can. Very confused. Wish you well too. Love Benja xx
Posts.Title: Finished fec and start tax on Wednesday but feeling really nervous...

Posts.Content: Dear Sasha Rose I am sorry to hear that you're haing such a bad time. I felt that I wanted to post for you, I cannot offer any great advise as I have not been through the treatment yet and cannot imagine all of the hardships you have been through. You are a wonderful lady who always has good advice and a listening ear for us fledglings to this horrible process and we are all very lucky to have you on this site with the other survivors to give your knowledge. I hope you can find a way through and we are all here for you, to support you. Stoksie, I am sorry to read your post and the problems that you're having . I would be happy to help and support you. In my previous life (before this journey which started in September) I was a director and solicitor in a law firm who specialised in family law, I have 25 years experience. I am not practicising at present due to circumstances but would be happy to offer a shoulder to lean on and some practical support if I can in this difficult time. Please feel free to personal message me if you want. We all need help and I certainly have assistance from the other ladies here. Love to all Benja xx

Posts.Title: Finished fec and start tax on Wednesday but feeling really nervous...

Posts.Content: Hi Karan and Stoksie, thank you for the replies. I didn't have any tests before my reconstruction, I kept my skin so now I'm thinking maybe I shouldn't have. Thanks for all the support, will let you know what happens. Cyber hugs to all on this s##### journey. Benja xx
Posts.Title: New lump!

Posts.Content: Hi all, just found a lump on my newly constructed side, it's not a fold of fatty necrosis as I have this at the top and this unfortunately is very much a lump! Didn't sleep last night worrying as had Mascetomy over two years ago and now after chemo and rads, had my long awaited reconstruction in mid December. I have been in touch with BCN and am being referred to breast consultant again. Just thought I had escaped from this round of appointments and here I am again. Pretty fed up. Has anyone else found a lump following surgery and can I hope that this is to do with the reconstruction and not the horrible critter again! Sorry to moan as I know you all have your worries. Benja xx
Posts.Title: New lump!

Posts.Content: Hi Aroma Mum, I remortgaged in October following my diagnosis in September. I was still in work at the time but was never asked about my health . I also took a buy to let mortgage in April following mx and chemo and again not asked about my health. The mortgage comp were just interested in ability to pay! I was lucky as had insured my income through a work policy so I still receive 75% of my income which has been a life saver. I have travelled abroad three times on short haul as well. I took insure pink insurance prior to surgery and treatment to go to Turkey. I now have a year insurance with Staysure for multi trip worldwide cover. I am not covered for 'metastatic disease' but figure that I will not get Breast cancer whilst I am away that needs to be dealt with, I had it over 12 months before I was diagnosed last year. Not sure if this helps. With over insurance cover, I had a critical illness policy which paid out some monies but have been told that I cannot be covered again for another 5 years post treatment. I do however have life insurance in place which remains unchanged. It is confusing and upsetting. I tell everyone now to make sure they have insurance in place as it's so difficult to (a) get financial help as lots of the ladies are finding and you just don't need that on top of everything and (b) to get cover following the event. Good luck in your quest and let us know if you find any good insurance companies! Benja x
Posts.Title: borrowing money

Posts.Content: Hi, some hospitals won't let you leave with drains in, so check, mine did and I came out with two in. Had to drain the bags each day and phone in the results (saved a hospital trip,each day). One drain was removed a week after surgery, the other two weeks as I seemed to have a lot of fluid still coming out. Everyone is different. I too had a little cotton bag to carry them in, used to put a plastic bag round the material bag for the shower. I was unable to sleep or rest until I had my MX but after I became very calm and perhaps accepting? I healed well and didn't experience any problems. Thinking of you, sending cyber hugs to you. Benja xx

Posts.Content: Thanks Kiera. As you say lots of things run though your mind at these times. I am going to speak to the beast nurse tomorrow and hopeful will receive some reassurances . Hope your biopsy goes well on Thursday,mine unfortunately was inconclusive before I went into surgery but i knew it was likely to be infected,intuition. I am out the otherside and so will you be soon. Good luck. Benja x
Posts.Title: Inflamed Lymph Nodes

Posts.Content: Morning Ladies. I went to see my breast surgeon on Friday and was told that they has removed 10 lymph nodes during op and that the sentinel node was the only infected node. I still need to undergo chemo etc but was feeling fairly positive. Late last night I found inflamed nodes in my left groin area. I can feel them, when I was told about my inflamed lymphs under my arm I could never feel them. Now am paranoid that the cancer has spread around the body! Has anyone else out there experienced this? Is this normal? I am unsure who I can contact and whether I am worrying unnecessarily. All replies welcome, this is just a roller coaster journey. Love 2 all Benja xx
Posts.Title: Inflamed Lymph Nodes

Posts.Content: Hi Bevb47, I too had the 'T' , Doxatacel, back in 2013. I suffered with my joints and was prescribed dixarit which is used for pains in bones as well as being an antidepressant. This helped a great deal as the normal pain killers do not touch the pain. I had lots of extreme side effects to this particular chemo so learnt a lot quickly! If in pain do ask, they can prescribe lots of things to help but don't until you have them! You can and will get through these, keep ticking them off, one by one. Good luck Benja xx
Posts.Title: 5th chemo

Posts.Content: I agree Whiskers, it does feel like we go round in circles sometimes, but we are being looked after and although that involves a certain amount of poking and prodding and testing. I too am viewed as being a strong person so 'hold it together' most of the time and like you expected to have some normality by now. I have written off the rest of this year for the construction etc and am aiming for January and a new year ( thought it would be 2014!) . Hang on in there girl, we have come a long way and although are journey maybe more complicated than others we have kicked butt and can help others whilst they are on their journey. It's another hurdle for you to get over but you've already come a long way. We will all support you in your continued fight ! Feel like a rant and rave, as I said, here's the place, use the anger/frustration to carry you through the next treatments/tests, we're all rooting for you, you are not alone. Benja xx
Posts.Title: never ending :(

Posts.Content: Hi Whiskers, like you I read the posts but seldom post now. I have had very similar treatment to you, except just turned 46, I had a MX with node removal November 2012, chemo 6FEC-T, had bad time with T, to extent that was left with neuropathy and burnt out my thyroid. Had 15 rads and am on Tamoxifen. Have had tamoxifen stopped for month as suffering with breathlessness and if it turns out to be tamoxifen they may have to force me into an early menopause, which will have a load more problems and side effects on new medication. I am presently awaiting a date for my reconstruction hopefully end of September beginning of October which in turn I hope will make me feel more 'normal', whatever that is! I don't like having a skin saver in, whilst I appreciate that it's done its job (stretched the skin) it goes hard, puckers and I have the portacath to fill it protruding from my ribs which hurts with bras and gets sore/bruised. My husband does not see me naked, I hide away, I have put on weight, have thin/bald patches on my head ( recently highlighted when watching a video of swimming with dolphins, when I was focused on how my bald patches showed up!) and feel generally unattractive. I identify with what you are feeling, I too get frustrated. I am going into hospital Thursday to have my heart artificially 'speeded up' to check my arteries and blood tests for B12 deficiencies . I never went near doctors before all this started. My whole life turned upside down, I was a professional person, have not returned to my old job as I do not feel able to do it, am in leaving talks which have got protracted and have had to involve solicitors! I am however here, on the forum discussing with you the downs of the treatment but I do recognise lots of positives. I am alive, I sadly attended a friends funeral after he lost his battle with this horrid disease, on Friday. We have come out battle scarred the other side but no one perceives us as we see ourselves. Everyone likes my shorter, curly hair and don't see the bald patches. In clothes people can't tell I have one breast so strangers don't know ( unless my kids tell them, 'my mum only has one boob!' Which has been known, it breaks the ice) . I am not my old self but in some ways I am better, I am less stressed, see my kids/family/friends more, appreciate the smaller things in life that I didn't before. It's not easy and I too have down days but we have a new life and people who have stuck with us, will continue to, they may not understand, because they haven't been through it but they will support you. Meanwhile you can rant and rave on here with people who identify with you and understand. Please have the pain looked at by the experts, it will be worth it in the end. Keep strong and sending lots of cyber hugs. If you need to chat please contact me. Sorry I have rambled on but I felt it important for you to know you're not alone in what you are feeling, sometimes that can help. Benja xx
Posts.Title: never ending :(

Posts.Content: Hi I was prescribed amitriptyline for the pain and it worked well. I took it in the morning before the TAXand seemed to reduce the pain I suffered. Good luck with the TAX but don't suffer with the pain they can prescribe pain killers to ease it. There is enough to content with without suffering in silence. I have now finished my last one so good luck to you all there is light at the end of the tunnel. Benja x
Posts.Title: 1st tax and legs ache

Posts.Content: Well done you! Another tick in the box. Onwards to the Rads. Big Hugs Benja x
Posts.Title: Today I am a cancer survivor :)

Posts.Content: Hi, I am in a slightly different position from you. I have been on long term sick for two years since October 2012 and decided that I could not return to my previous employment due to the stress factors and amount of hours I was working. Handed my notice in September and have 6 months notice period which I won't work as still signed off and  awaiting reconstruction surgery on 15th December. I decided I would do something completely different and brought a business, totally different to what I have worked in for 27 years. It will allow me flexibility after my recovery from surgery and i am planning on developing an online side and planned parties etc. my point is could you do something from home that would allow you to work when you are able Or set up a little business? Do you have some skills ? Coming up to christmas you could make and sell some things whilst looking around? Whatever you do  I am sure it will be a success, good luck with your journey and your career choice. Benja x
Posts.Title: looking for work after cancer

Posts.Content: Hi I feel slightly different, in the beginning (September 2012) I felt numb, bemused and over whelmed by the whole process and the replacement of my life with hospital appointments and treatments. It was not until February 2013 that I turned my work phone off and have never switched it back on. The whole process has made me re evaluate my life and I realised that I was not enjoying my career and that I had no work life balance and was running to catch up the whole time. As a result I resigned from my employment in September ( having not returned) and am on my notice period. 27 years of my career so it was scary but I am so much happier. I still don't like that I am not me physically with all of the drug side effects but I have to say I am less stressed and spend lots of time with my kids which they probably have grown tired of LOL !  This is a positive for me and I try to concentrate on this rather than the other very much more negative effects that we all go through. Love to all on this very difficult and life changing roller coaster. Benja xx
Posts.Title: feeling sad and angry after having had breast cancer

Posts.Content: Dear D.Loung I am sorry that you find yourself on this site but you will find lots of support here. I was told that I had probably had cancer for over.a year when I had my diagnosis and it was small. It really depends on the type of cancer. You will know more once you have the results. At the moment you are imagining the worst which is understandable, you will have to deal with things as they arise and one step at a time. It is a long journey and you will need to support each other. Your mum will let you know how she wants the support, we all react differently. Right now enjoy each others company, the one thing that my journey has taught me is that you must live for now. Your mum will cope with the treatments with help from the professionals and from you all, it is doable but daunting now, it is the unknown. There are many more on this forum who will provide more wisdom than I but we are all here to help you. Don't suffer in silence and keep posting to,let us know the results and how you all are. The unfortunate symptom of cancer is that it has a ripple effect, it does not just effect the person who is going through the treatment. Wish you and your mother all the best and my fingers are crossed for good news for you all. Cyber hugs Benja x
Posts.Title: Mums got breast cancer, I'm really at a lost
